lg.l: WHAT Doctor, if great CARTERET CondescendsTo chat with S──t and you, as private Friends,Ans. Their Visits for the Favour, make amends.Must you so silly be, to tell the Town,And boast of Favours, he may blush to own?Ans. Was ever such a Piece of Nonsense known!Is this the Modest, Dutiful, Behaviour,You shew your Patron, for so great a Favour?Ans. Thy Muse is damn'd, and no Reprieve can save her.Think you, these Honours, to thy Merit due,What equal Honours can reflect from you?Ans. You wou'd not ask the Question, if you knew.You may, perhaps, propose Immortal Fame,Under the Shelter of your Patron's Name:Ans. Great Maro with Augustus, did the same.If you presume too far, you miss that end,For the like Course Sw──t lost his Gall's-town Friend.Ans. That you may ne're have one to lose──God send.And may in time disturb your Patron too,To see the simple choice he made, of you.Ans. To read your simple Stuff, wou'd make him spew.But is my Lord still short of his Intent, 4}Or is thy Merit of that vast extent,That nothing less than Thousands can Content?Ans. Whilst I, for lack of Farthings, Nonsense vent.There was a time when Paddy out of hope, 4}Thought a West-Indian jaunt his utmost Scope;Ans. There was a time when Johnny out of hope, Indies to avoid the Rope.The World's well mended since with Patrick, nowNothing but Visto's, and Canals will do.Ans. 'Twere much more mended, if you honest grew.But pray, great Sir, what Friend of common SenseWou'd labour to promote such vain Expence?Ans. While I, in Garret starve, for want of Pence.And must your Brethren all in Hamlets dwell,To adorn your Busts, and young St. Patrick's Cell?Ans. Such Saints as you, are fit to People Hell.Why may not some of them, for ought you know,Have a desire to build, or to bestow,Ans. On John, a Gibbet for his Numbers low.Retrench then, and be Modest, if you can Sir,Or raise Objections, stronger than your Answer,Ans. Retrench thy Vices, or you'll dye a Dancer.Think Doctor, after double Vicar, double Rector,A dignity in Christ-Church City Lecture,Ans. Thou double Dunce, to slander thy Protector.And something else, which you have still forgotA College-place: Won't all this boil the Pot;Ans. Thou'lt ne'er be witty, whilst thy Head is hot.Then judge, how very aukwardly it looks,You have not yet enough, to buy you Books,Ans. Thou get'st 'em cheaper──if we credit Br──ks.Good Patrick, take Advice, and first read o'erThe Books you have, before you call for more,Ans. And those you have purloin'd, good Jack restore.Resign some of those Cures you labour hard in,If you must spend whole Summers in your Garden,Ans. Thy labours, Johnny, are not worth one Farthing.Attend some one at least, and quit Glass-Nevin,Which will destroy your Credit, if you live in,Ans. To Jack, no Credit ever yet was given,
